page.title: 13THE CHATTERTON RIOT IN 1826
page.content: In the early years of the 19th century the Corn Laws were introduced to protect farmers,which made the price of bread high.The factory workers believed that if they smashed all the new machines it would make more work for them,so that they could afford the higher bread prices. On{23 April 1826},rioters from Haslingden came to{Chatterton}.They came to smash power looms which they feared would put them out of work,at Aitken's mill.They were met by armed soldiers and Major Grant,the local magistrate.Major Grant read the Riot Act and told the rioters to go home. They refused and in the following fight six people were killed and many injured.Later the ringleaders were arrested and sentenced to death.
